conclusion: Analyze whether light can undergo total internal reflection when exiting a transparent spherical medium after entering it at an angle.
Light ray incident at point A on a spherical medium with center O, angle of incidence labeled as i.
Using Snell's law: n₁sin(i) = n₂sin(r), sin(r) = sin(i)/n₂, since n₂ > 1, r < i (ray bends toward the normal).
Ray travels through the sphere after refraction at A, reaches point B on the opposite side, attempts to exit.
At point B, using Snell's law: n₂sin(i') = n₁sin(i_out), sin(i_out) = n₂sin(i').
Total internal reflection occurs when sin(i_out) > 1, physically impossible, happens when n₂sin(i') > 1.
Critical angle for total internal reflection: sin(i'_critical) = n₁/n₂ = 1/n₂.
Total internal reflection occurs if i' > i'_critical.
Geometry of the system: radius of sphere is R, OA = OB = R.
Angle i' depends on ray path through sphere, related to angle r and sphere geometry.
If initial angle i is large enough, refracted ray path leads to i' exceeding critical angle.
Final answer: Yes, when incident angle i is large enough, light will be totally internally reflected when attempting to exit the sphere.
Incident angle i must be large enough for ray's path through sphere to result in internal incident angle i' at point B exceeding critical angle.
Exact threshold value of i depends on refractive index n₂ and can be calculated using geometric relationships between angles and sphere's radius.
